Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=WINDOWS-1252;
	format=flowed

Rob,

In version 1.6, you can turn off mechanism validation when you run 
c=
k2cti.  But this was added after version 1.5.5. You can always modify 
the =
source code yourself if you can compile version 1.5.5 or earlier. 
What you=
 need to do is set 'validate' to 'false' when calling CKReader 
from ck2cti=
.   Alternatively, if it is only a few reactions, you could 
comment them o=
ut in the chemkin file, and then add them by hand in the 
cti file.

But I =
think there is a bigger problem.  Even if the non-integral 
stoichiometric =
coefficients occur only on the product side of 
irreversible reactions (so =
there is no problem with reaction orders), 
the procedure used to compute s=
pecies production rates assumes integral 
stoichiometric coefficients, sinc=
e it uses addition operations, rather 
than multiplies, to compute species =
production rates from reaction 
rates of progress.  This is done for speed,=
 but probably could be 
modified to handle non-integral coefficients withou=
t much if any 
decrease in speed. The relevant code is in class C_AnyN in f=
ile 
StoichManager.h, which is used to handle stoichiometric coefficients 
=
other than 1, 2, or 3.  It shouldn't be hard to modify.

But it might be ea=
sier to modify the mechanism.  If the reactions have 
only non-integral pro=
duct stoichiometric coefficients, representing 
multiple product channels, =
is it possible to replace the reaction with 
two or more reactions with int=
egral stoichiometric coefficients?

Dave


On Apr 26, 2005, at 12:43 PM, Tr=
anter, Robert Simon wrote:

>
> Dave,
> I have modified the ck2cti code to =
read non integer stoichiometries 
> such as those in the 1 atm soot model f=
rom Howard et al. 
> (http://web.mit.edu/anish/www/mitsootmodel1atmsymp2004=
.mec). However I 
> still have one stumbling block to using this mechanism =
with Cantera. 
> Due to the structure of part of the thermo file for this m=
echanism I 
> will have to hand edit a small section of the cti file produc=
ed by 
> ck2cti which is no great problem. This arises because several of t=
he 
> spceis have atom counts that are too large for the standard thermo 
>=
 file structure. The automatic reaction checking in ck2cti appears to 
> be=
 preventing the cti file from being written because the reactions 
> involv=
ing species from the thermo file with non-standard composition 
> definitio=
ns do not balance. Is it possible to turn off the automatic 
> reaction che=
cking in ck2cti thereby allowing the cti file to be 
> created?
> =A0
> If =
you would like a copy of the modified ckparser.cpp file I wold

send it to you.

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/enriched;
	charset=WINDOWS-1252

Rob, 


In version 1.6, you can turn off mechanism validation when you run
=
ck2cti.  But this was added after version 1.5.5. You can always modify
the =
source code yourself if you can compile version 1.5.5 or earlier.
What you =
need to do is set 'validate' to 'false' when calling CKReader
from ck2cti. =
  Alternatively, if it is only a few reactions, you could
comment them out =
in the chemkin file, and then add them by hand in the
cti file. 


But I th=
ink there is a bigger problem.  Even if the non-integral
stoichiometric coe=
fficients occur only on the product side of
irreversible reactions (so ther=
e is no problem with reaction orders),
the procedure used to compute specie=
s production rates assumes
integral stoichiometric coefficients, since it u=
ses addition
operations, rather than multiplies, to compute species product=
ion
rates from reaction rates of progress.  This is done for speed, but
pro=
bably could be modified to handle non-integral coefficients without
much if=
 any decrease in speed. The relevant code is in class C_AnyN in
file Stoich=
Manager.h, which is used to handle stoichiometric
coefficients other than 1=
, 2, or 3.  It shouldn't be hard to modify. 


But it might be easier to mo=
dify the mechanism.  If the reactions have
only non-integral product stoich=
iometric coefficients, representing
multiple product channels, is it possib=
le to replace the reaction with
two or more reactions with integral stoichi=
ometric coefficients?  


Dave
